title: A case of osteoarticular melioidosis misdiagnosed as extra-pulmonary tuberculosis from low endemicity region in North-western India.
location_name: Vardhman Mahavir Medical College and Safdarjung Hospital, Delhi
retrieved_preview:
Melioidosis is caused by a facultative intracellular gram-negative bacterium, Burkholderia pseudomallei.
[1] It is rapidly developing clinical infection particularly in patients with risk factors of diabetes mellitus, hazardous alcohol use, chronic renal disease, chronic pulmonary disease, immunosuppression and malignancy [2]. title: The Hidden Threat: Polyarticular Septic Arthritis Unmasking Disseminated Melioidosis.
retrieved_preview:
Polyarticular septic arthritis with an atypical course should prompt evaluation for melioidosis, as early recognition and targeted antimicrobial therapy are essential to prevent dissemination and relapse.

Septic arthritis is a common orthopedic emergency which causes significant mortality and morbidity. It is noted to have a case fatality rate of 5–15% and irreversible joint damage in 25–50% patients afflicted [1]. Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species are the most common causative organism;

title: A Rare Case of Melioidosis Breast Abscess in Far North Queensland.
retrieved_preview: Melioidosis is a rare tropical infection caused by the Gram-negative bacterial organism Burkholderia pseudomallei, which often resides in soil, water, and plants [1,2]. During January 1998-December 2019, the annual incidence of melioidosis in Far North Queensland, Queensland, Australia, more than doubled [3]. Patients with melioidosis have varying presentations, including pneumonia, skin infections, and intra-abdominal organ abscesses, all of which can lead to septicemia [4,5]. We present a 67-y

title: Acute and Chronic Presentation of Melioidosis: (18) F-FDG PET/CT Case Series.

Melioidosis is an infectious disease that is caused by a gram-negative bacillus,
Burkholderia pseudomallei
, which is highly endemic in South and Southeast Asia, as well as in northern Australia, due to its widespread distribution across tropical regions. Infection is caused by inoculation, inhalation, and ingestion,

title: Mortality among hospitalized children with melioidosis in Thailand: a retrospective national database analysis (2015-2023).
retrieved_preview: Research in contextEvidence before this studyWe searched PubMed using combinations of the terms melioidosis OR Burkholderia pseudomallei AND (pediatric OR child OR children) AND (Thailand OR Thai) AND (mortality OR outcome OR epidemiology), and screened reference lists of key reviews; we included English and Thai studies reporting human data and prioritized peer-reviewed literature.
